\appendix
\section{Conventions and Rules}
\label{conventions}
In performing type II T-duality and lifts to M theory, we will
(mostly) use the conventions
found in \cite{Johnson:2000ch}. Let $\ell_p$ denote the
eleven-dimensional Planck scale, and $\ell_s$ denote the string scale. 

\subsection{Lifting IIA to M theory}

A type IIA SUGRA configuration can be lifted to 11 dimensions.  Let
$y$ parametrize the eleventh direction. The $y$
coordinate is compact with periodicity $2\pi$.  Writing the 11-dimensional
fields on the left and the IIA fields on the right, we have:

\begin{eqnarray}
G_{\mu\nu} &=& e^{-\frac{2}{3}\Phi}G_{\mu\nu}^{(IIA)} + 
e^{\frac{4}{3}\Phi}C_\mu C_\nu \non\\
G_{\mu y} &=& -\ell_p e^{\frac{4}{3}\Phi}C_\mu \non\\
G_{yy} &=& \ell_p^2 e^{\frac{4}{3}\Phi} \\
A_{\mu\nu\rho} &=& C_{\mu\nu\rho} \non\\
A_{\mu\nu y} &=& \ell_p B_{\mu\nu}. \non
\end{eqnarray}

\subsection{T-Duality}

We dualize in the direction $x$, which we scale to have periodicity $2\pi$
(and is hence dimensionless).

The NS-NS fields transform in the following manner:
\begin{eqnarray}
e^{2\Phi'} &=& \frac{\ell_s^2 e^{2\Phi}}{G_{xx}} \non\\
G_{xx}' &=& \frac{\ell_s^4}{G_{xx}} \non\\
G_{\mu x}' &=& \frac{\ell_s^2 B_{\mu x}}{G_{xx}} \\
G_{\mu\nu}' &=& G_{\mu\nu} - \frac{G_{\mu x}G_{\nu x} - B_{\mu x}B_{\nu x}}{G_{xx}}
\non\\
B_{\mu x}' &=& \frac{\ell_s^2 G_{\mu x}}{G_{xx}} \non\\
B_{\mu\nu}' &=& B_{\mu\nu} - \frac{B_{\mu x}G_{\nu x} - G_{\mu x}B_{\nu x}}{G_{xx}}.
\non
\end{eqnarray}

The transformation of the R-R potentials is given by
\begin{eqnarray}
\ell_s^{-1}{C_{\mu\cdots\nu\alpha x}^{(n)}}' &=& C_{\mu\cdots\nu\alpha}^{(n-1)} -
(n-1)\frac{C_{[\mu\cdots\nu|x}^{(n-1)}G_{|\alpha]x}}{G_{xx}} \\
\ell_s {C_{\mu\cdots\nu\alpha\beta}^{(n)}}' &=&
C_{\mu\cdots\nu\alpha\beta x}^{(n+1)} + nC_{[\mu\cdots\nu\alpha}^{(n-1)}B_{\beta]x}
+ n(n-1)\frac{C_{[\mu\cdots\nu|x}^{(n-1)}B_{|\alpha|x}G_{|\beta]x}}{G_{xx}}. \non
\end{eqnarray}

%We also use the convention that $\ast dC^{(2n)} = dC^{(8-2n)}$ in type IIB,
%while in type IIA we have $\ast dC^{(1)} = dC^{(7)}$ and
%$\ast dC^{(3)} = dC^{(5)}$, which imply that $\ast dC^{(5)} = -dC^{(3)}$ and
%$\ast dC^{(7)} = -dC^{(1)}$.
